Hi, I wrote to you a few months ago about pursuing music and great news! I am! Bad news, I'm terribly inexperienced. I switched schools mid semester and uh oh turns out everyone around me is very experienced and skilled and I am not. I'm telling myself that I'll catch up and I shouldn't be jealous of those who've had more experience. But there's a little voice in my head that tells me that it's too late, I've missed my shot, I can't become good at anything starting age 17 and I should just give up. Now I can't say if this is true, but if it is please tell me and I'll just go back to studying to become an engineer, which is 1000x less fulfilling but at least I'm good at it

i'm not sure, but i can say that out of the many elements that make up what i do, some of them i learned at age 2, some of them i learned at age 5, some of them i learned at age 8, some of them i learned at age 12, some of them i learned at age 15, some of them i learned at age 19, etc. on and on and on and on. i've been learning new things at every age all the way up until the present. video making was one of the most recent things i learned, and i still have a lot to learn there

I'm kinda fascinated by people who have a singular passion and never stray from tgat path because they love that one thing so much. Us normal folk struggle to understand and I bet the answer to a lot of the questions you get like "how did you become so good?" is a simple "I just love music more than anything else". Is this true for you or were there actually things you had to sacrifice to get good?

never had to sacrifice anything to 'get good', but i had to make some sacrifices to bring some of those skills into a tangibly applicable form, and to impliment them at a high enough volume to catch the attention of viewers around the world such as you
Because I have a feeling therewas never anything in your life that you liked more than music, not money, not school, not friends.
visual expression is nice too, as well as words/language, and shapes and patterns
And people without a singular passion just will never be able to do that because doing music for them is a conscious desire while for you it's more like a personality trait
it's not as singular as you may think ... and i think some sacrifices have to be made to get it to at least follow a slightly singular path, at least enough to be constructed into reality

I'm asking specifically about your answers to the questions "what are some songs with only 2 chords" and "with only 1 chord". You listed like a total of 20 songs of various genres, periods and levels of popularity. Did you have to look them up or do you just know all these songs by heart including their chords?

i went browsing through my itunes, to remind me of songs, but i generally know what they sound like without listening. in some cases i went searching to make sure there weren't any other parts. for example, many songs i knew the main sections were 2 chords, but i went searching around the song to make sure it didn't have something at the end that i forgot about, etc. For example, it's like if someone says "name someone who only wears red, white, and yellow." Ronald McDonald may come to mind, but i might just take a glance just to make sure there isn't a bit of blue somewhere that i forgot about. i hope that makes sense

(ref: q.php?date=201901272004)1.27.198:04 pm what is your set up for this? how can i do that

Hey, i'm just now learning about intervals and harmonies and stuff and i've been listening to this song and it just confused me. (https://youtu.be/GC6nSX67Q-4?t=31 i linked to the relevant part at 31 sec). Listen to the guitar melody, it has these notes in it, ignoring all the little thrills and slides, - F# B A C#. And then the second guitar comes in and harmonizes over the first and I figured out that the harmony is a minor third (correct me if im wrong). But here's the confusion: the notes in the harmony are A D C# E, and A D E are all a minor third of the corresponding notes in guitar 1 - F# B C#. BUT the C# in guitar 2 is a MAJOR THIRD away from the A in guitar 1. And it sounds bloody cool. What's going on here, why isn't that C# a C, and why does changing that one note make it sound so much better?

let's skip the harmony and just look at melodies. in most songs, they don't use all the notes. they tend to use some, but kind of skip the ones in between. typically if you lay out all 12 notes in order, xxxxxxxxxxxx, an ordinary song for example usually is only gonna use these notes 0x0x00x0x0x0. you'll notice that's uneven. and if you're wondering what happens when it's completely evenly distributed: 0x0x0x0x0x0x, well you'll notice it sounds like you are spinning around. i've still left most of life's most important questions unanswered, but hopefully this is a more direct way of accessing the conundrum you mentioned, which has nothing to do with harmony

hey bill, it's the dom9no3 chord guy whose question you didn't follow when I initially asked it. This is what I was getting at (more fleshed out). The dom9 chord (e.g. G9: G-B-D-F-A) is probably the most consonant
consonant? not sure what that means here

combination of 5 notes that we have in the 12-note scale. In lots of compositions, chords are more frequently thought of in 4 voices instead of 5 (thank u bach chorales), so we frequently encounter chords that are 4 out of the 5 notes of a dominant 9 chord. Using the G chord, we have G7 = G9 no9, Gadd9 = G9 no7, Dm6 = B hdim7 = G9 no1, and I sometimes also see G9 approximated in 4 voices by leaving out the 5th. These four are all pretty common chords, all quite consonant. But the 5th 4-pitch chord coming from the dom9 that should be just as consonant as the other 4 is G9 no3 = {D,F,G,A} = d minor add4.

i'd call it Dmin over G, which is rampantly common, especially in the 1970s 'funk' sort of things. it can be used in the place of G9 or Gmin9. you wouldn't have to specify. james brown songs use these all day. i use them all the time
The frequency I see minor add4 chords in leadsheets and such is basically zero compared to the other 4 chords that are dom9 chords omitting 1 of the 5 notes.

if you put the bass on G, which i think is where it's supposed to be according to your study, i think you will find it much more commonly. or actually perhaps the lead sheet will just say G9 or Gmin9 but in reality the execution will leave out the 3rd
Do you feel there is a good reason for this?
this study is not really taking account for where the bass is
Is the the minor add4 chord lacking something musically that makes it rare compared to the other chords mentioned, even though it should ""theoretically"" sound just as reasonable?

i'm not following why it 'should theoretically' sound just as reasonable, but if you feel it has been under-used, you now have an opportunity to find and demonstrate its goodness. if you find that it really is not so good, then it is only you who can explain why you don't like it

"Just did a bad thing" is the most addictive piece of music ive ever heard. it's structured so perfectly. what happened that made you come up with that song?

nothing really, that first line is just one of many other song ideas from a song idea generating session. not even the best one, probably one of the worst actually. but the reason it got picked for recording was due to time constraints. i kept narrowing it down and ended up excluding all the choices for not being good enough until i narrowed it down to 1 but then i excluded that one too for not being good enough. 'bad thing' was excluded way earlier, because it was one of the least good. so after having eventually excluding them all for not being good enough, i realized i was at a dead end and the clock was running out so for a twist i just kind of picked one of the worst ones, and wrote it extremely quickly. this was actually an advantage, because when you try to make a bad thing good in a very short amount of time, you are forced to bring out your very best. it's kind of like when it's 8:59 and the bread store is closing at 9:00, you will discover some automobile maneuvering skills you perhaps didn't know you had, just to get that bread

About four years ago I finally stepped into making and singing music after growing up in an family that believed music making, esp singing, is the realm of an elite few talented people. About 6 mo ago I leveled up again in my understanding of music and began making/recording my own music and performing more on my own time, not just with my group. So, I know my strongest suit is harmony and singing with others, but recently at a mic night I sang a song (used a mic) by myself, no accompanymnent, which is a first for me. Icould hear myself during and it I was delighted that my voice both sounded and felt good, which i have learned are some of several markers that you are making a good, strong sound. But a friend recorded it, then sent it to me later. I watched it to see what it sojnded like from an audiences persective and it actually didn't sound great, not bad but not good. There were a few notes I thought I nailed but were actually a little shaky, and overall tone was not as strong as I had felt it was in the moment. How did the 'La de da de da de da de day oh' song come to be? It sounds so good to me! It probably was similar to the process of other songs, but I'm asking because, in my opinion, it really stands out, and I want to know more about it.

this may sound boring and technical but i wrote some of it on a writing session, then wrote a bit more of it on a writing session, and then finally wrote the remainder of the song during a writing session. that's the short story. the long story is, i was doing a writing session many many years ago after many years of not doing writing sessions. actually it felt like i had never done a writing session before, it had been so long. i know i did many years before that, but it seemed so far away and i'm not quite sure how i ever did it. too long ago to remember really, and the world had surely changed since then, mine and everyone else's. so i was doing something which i think might have been totally new, i was just writing. not in the recording thing, not trying to record and write at the same time, just writing. like on paper, and i had 1 instrument to play along to what i was singing, and weirdly it was an unplugged bass. which doesn't quite make sense but it was a quiet room and i was just using it to indicate chords. not play chords, but just play the bass notes to indicate chords. so a few things were written on that session, including a thing that looked like (ref: snow32909.jpg">this. you may mostly recognize this verse, sort of mostly. but the chorus it goes to on this page (not shown) is completely different, and wraps up to a surprise twist ending very quickly, making it a probably less than 1 minute piece called, presumably, 'in the snow.' the snow not really being the chorus, the snow being the twist ending. so that's 'in the snow.' fast forward maybe 3 and a half years. i am getting my life togther and going through the stacks and stacks of writing sessions i've done over the years, and getting it all organized and doing writing on them, for days and days and days and days and weeks, a many months long writing-only period i call 'writing tare' when i worked only on writing for almost a year, and not starting any new ones, just updating/continuing/finishing/fixing on existing songs and fragments. very early on in this process, around september 2012, i took a look at 'in the snow,' made some small adjustments to the verse to make it stronger, the pre-chorus got changed from 'i'm gonna count to 3' to instead 'i'm gonna write a song'. therefore the old chorus didn't make sense (something about counting to 3 i assume) ditched it and wrote a brand new much brighter stronger chorus, which <a href="https://billwurtz.com/la-de-da-chorus.jpg)as you can see seems to be nearly exactly the la de da chorus. and then it sat there burning a hole in my shelf, as a ray of sunshine with a high standard i suppose i was afraid to live up to. fast forward to 2017, i've been actually recording songs, and videos of many different types, for many years at this point, and over the years the writing list had grown out of control, mostly from 2010 to 2013 but still even more later, so most of the time doing a song (recording + video) means going through the list and finding something i want to do. in post-hotewig i had made the decision to allow fragments to be picked (songs where only partial writing was done) so as to get something almost entirely new and finish the writing on the spot and record it. out of something like 400 to choose from, i manually got it down to about 41 finalists, planning to do a random number selection to choose. but i narrowed it down again manually to 27, and with agonizing fear i chose the number and it picked la de da. and then the next day i had terrible cold feet about it, thought it was lame and stupid. switched it to a slow song, switched it to another song, lost my mind, wasn't sure, and then somewhere around getting into the haircut chair (was planning on doing real video performance footage for this one) i was pondering a second verse after the bright la de da chorus, and the first 3 mall lines tumbled into my head quite readily. so at least that mostly solidified the song choice for me and gave it an extra push toward validity, and from there the decision was finalized and i quickly finished the writing and then went into production which took agonizingly long because it turns out going on camera in front of zillions of people can be scary if you haven't been doing it regularly

When I want to change keys, I have the choice between 11 different keys. How do I know which key I want to change into?

don't worry about that. simply listen to the song all up to its current point, and imagine what you want the next part to sound like. then find out what those notes and chords were. then the analysts (maybe you, maybe someone else, ...) can try to figure out what key they went to. sometimes people may even disagree on what key it was, because when you change keys you have opened the door to change, and sometimes you may be roaming the hallways instead of going explicitly into 1 room. or in some cases you may have entered a room but through the side door, which can cause potential disagreements about which key it was. but it still sounds the way it sounds so just pay attention to what sound you want. unless you are making music primarily for a wall decoration, in which case you should use B# major, to wow your guests

There's a song where one bar of the verse sounds like it's in 4/4 time and the next bar sounds like it's in 3/4 so it sounds like the verse just alternates between 4/4 and 3/4 but I wanted to know what time signature this is since I assume it doesn't just constantly switch back and forth (for clarification it goes 1 2 3 4 | 1 2 3 | 1 23 4 |)

whoever writes it down gets to decide. it depends which way you think is easier to read. you can say 7/4 if you don't mind your bars being huge. you can make the bars reasonable size if you don't mind writing 4/4 then 3/4 etc. at the beginning of every bar. or, what i've actually seen, is you can write something like 4/4 + 3/4, at the beginning. and that means that it alternates. that's probably what i might do. no, what happened is i finally realized once and for all that youtube is now recommending videos much more if they have stronger monetization. i have heard rumors that they would start doing this and knew they would eventually, but i proved it very clearly recently. because the ball and stick video was listed as #2 on trending when you click into the trending list, but, it was not showing up in recommendations where top 5 trending videos are supposed to show up. i did a test on a clean cookie-free (identity-free) browser, and went to youtube.com. on the front page of youtube, the top row of 5 videos is recommended trending videos. if you keep refreshing it, it seems to display mostly videos from the top 8 or so, switching around slightly with each refresh but usually mostly the same videos, all taken from the top of the trending list. but i refreshed it several times and mine was simply never there, despite being listed as #2 on the actual trending list. so i did an experiment and turned on 5 sec skippables for that video, and it instantly started appearing on the front page every time. so essentially this proves to me that the youtube algorhythm is strongly favoring videos with better monetization, which i always suspected would eventually be true. so essentially i can no longer trust youtube to give my videos a fair shake if they have the weakest monetization settings (i.e. display ads only). the good news is, i still offer all my content downloadable for free on billwurtz dot com, so they can be played in an offline video player of your choosing, which for me personally is the way i strongly prefer to watch content anyway. in fact i never even wanted to join youtube because i can't stand watching videos in an online streaming player. much prefer to download. but i gotta get the stuff on as many sites as possible, and play by their rules if necessary. after all that's probably how most of you found me

Out of curiosity I slowed down Mount St. Helens to listen more closely to the rhythm of the vocals during the parts where it sounds like you're singing too many syllables over one beat (e.g. "and it's gonna be a" on beat 4 of measure 1). What it seems like you are consistently doing is having three accents during the beat ("AND it's GONna BE a"), but when I listened more closely you aren't doing a triplet feel over the beat, but rather, depending on the words in each particular occurrence, a 3-3-2, 3-2-3, or 2-3-3 pattern of 32nd notes (which fits better with the 16th note rhythms in the instruments than a triplet would). My question is: are you intentionally writing the melody with 32nd note syncopation like that?
generally i'd say if you are hearing it differently as a result of slowing it down, that's probably not the way i was thinking it. i was writing it according to the speed it is on normal play mode

Or are you just thinking about doing 3 accents over the beat? Either way, I'm impressed. Either you're successfully performing a near-impossible rhythm that you've written, or you're naturally creating one by ear as you try to sing with the best feel you can.

there's a thing that comes up among people who are self taught with music or whatever people who do that are said to have "gaps in their knowledge"-stuff people with more formal education learned in school about proper technique or whatever. i always think that's a little strange to say because everybody has gaps in their knowledge, just the people who studied in school have all filled the same gaps. how do you recommend self taught musicians (like me) fill in those gaps? i kinda think if you pay enough attention to how other people do it, and you are somehow very relaxed yet focused, you can pretty much do whatever

really it's just like learning to read. the words don't change if you can't read, but reading/writing will help you communicate with the wider world. i'd say just get some song books. learn to read them. now that the internet is a thing, you can pretty much just look up everything you need to know 1 by 1. but i think song books would be the best thing, not only to become literate but it will probably introduce you to more songs and make you a stronger musical person in general
